mFHMOx-y6.memHandModelNotes: Do not restrict anthropogenic classes to ecotone buffer (i.e. successional grassland, pasture/hay, and developed open space). Only include utility swaths when within/adjacent to selected forested classes. Amy Silvano 24jun05

references.B94CHO01NAUS: Choate, J. R., J. K. Jones, Jr., and C. Jones. 1994. Handbook of mammals of the south-central states. Louisiana State University Press, Baton Rouge. 304 pp.
references.A86COO01SWGP: Cook, J.. 1986. The mammals of the Animas Mountains and adjacent areas, Hidalgo County, New Mexico. Occasional Papers the Museum of Southwestern Biology 4: 1-45.
references.B75FIN01SWGP: Findley, J. S., A. H. Harris, D. E. Wilson, and C. Jones. 1975. Mammals of New Mexico. University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 360 pages.
references.B04SCH01USGP: Schmidly, D. J. 2004. The mammals of Texas. Revised ed. University of Texas Press, Austin.
references.A58FIN01USGP: Findley, J.S. and B.E. Pullen. 1958. The fulvous harvest mouse in New Mexico. Journal of Mammalogy 39: 306-307.
references.A59HOF01USGP: Hoffmeister, D.F. 1959. Distributional records of certain mammals from southern Arizona. Southwestern Naturalist 4: 14-19.
references.R99WIL02SEGP: Wilson, D.E. and S. Ruff. 1999. The Smithsonian book of North American mammals. Washington, DC, Smithsonian Inst. Press. 750 p.
references.B86HOF01SWGP: Hoffmeister, D.F. 1986. Mammals of Arizona. University of Arizona Press. The University of Arizona Press and the Arizona Game and Fish Department, Tucson, Arizona. 602 pages.
references.A03JON01USGP:
Jones, Z.F., C.E. Bock and J.H. Bock. 2003. Rodent Communities in a Grazed and Ungrazed Arizona
Grassland, and a Model of Habitat Relation ships Among Rodents in Southwestern Grass/Shrublands. American Midland Naturalist 149: 384-394.

habitat_description:
Southwest:
Narrative description of distribution:  Hoffmeister (1986) was used as the primary source for delimiting range.  The Mammalian Species Account (Spencer and Cameron 1982) predated Hoffmeister (1986) by four years.  For New Mexico, Findley et al. (1975) and Cook (1986) were consulted.  This range is more narrowly defined than is depicted by the use of HUCs.  Range is overestimated in the northern extent of its range in both southeastern Arizona and southwestern New Mexico.  There is little information regarding the range of this species.  This species is known to occur within southeastern Arizona, and extreme southern New Mexico (Spencer and Cameron 1982).  In Arizona, Hoffmeister (1959) trapped this species in Cochise (n = 8), Santa Cruz (n = 16) and Pima Counties (n = 1).  In the Huachuca Mountains, this species was observed at the mouths of Miller (n = 2) and Ramsey Canyons (n  = 1) and at Broken Arrow Ranch, Miller Canyon (n = 1; Hoffmeister and Goodpaster 1954).  In New Mexico, this species is known to occur in the Animas (Cook 1986) and Peloncillo Mountains, Hidalgo County (Findley et al. 1975; Cook 1986).
Vegetation Type:  Mesquite and desert grassland vegetation types described as (1) grassy slopes and alluvial fans amid scattered oaks and other deciduous trees, (2) hillsides within gramma and other grasses and scattered beargrass, mesquite and yucca, (3) grassy, rocky alluvial fans containing oak- and pinyon-covered canyons, (4) desert shrubland, and (5) oak-juniper woodlands.
Elevational Range:  On the Peloncillo Mountains, New Mexico, this species was trapped at 5,900 feet elevation (Findley and Pullen 1958).  Because there is only one site specific location which represents an infinitesimally small n-value, this information does not satisfy EDR 5.  Consequently, this information will be excluded from further analysis.
Sensitivity to Human Disturbance:  In the Sonoita Valley, Santa Cruz County, this species was trapped significantly more often in ungrazed warm-season perennial bunchgrasses characterized by Aristida, Bouteloua, Eragrostis, Heteropogon, Hilaria and Lycurus, than in grazed shrubland characterized by scattered mesquite (Prosopis velutina), and a variety of emergent succulents including Agave palmeri, Yucca elata and Dasylirion wheeleri  (Z = 2.21; P < 0.05; Jones et al. 2003).   Dogs and humans did not greatly disturb this species, as they can become accustomed to their presence (Hoffmeister and Goodpaster 1954).  
Assessment:  There is a paucity of data regarding the habitat requirements of this species. References used in drafting this habitat description include the American Society of Mammalogists’ species account (Spencer and Cameron 1982), three peer reviewed journal articles (Findley and Pullen 1968; Hoffmeister 1959; Jones et al. 2003), and four natural history accounts (Hoffmeister and Goodpaster 1954; Findley et al. 1975; Cook 1986; Hoffmeister 1986).  Vegetation information was derived from two peer reviewed journal articles (Findley and Pullen 1968; Hoffmeister 1959), and three natural history accounts (Hoffmeister and Goodpaster 1954; Findley et al. 1975; Hoffmeister 1986).  Elevation was derived from one peer reviewed journal article (Findley and Pullen 1968).  Sensitivity to human disturbance was derived from one peer-reviewed journal article (Jones et al. 2003) and one natural history account (Hoffmeister and Goodpaster 1954).  Findley and Pullen (1958) trapped this mouse on the Peloncillo Mountains, 22 miles south and two miles east of Rodeo, Hidalgo County, from 27-30 January 1957.   Hoffmeister and Goodpaster (1954) conducted a mammal study in the Huachuca Mountains; field observations were made and specimens were collected by W.W. Goodpaster and L.W. Goodpaster in August 1949, August 1950, 31 July-3 August 1951, by D.F. Hoffmeister and R.G. Van Gelder 09 August – 01 September 1950, 31 July – 03 August 1951 and by D.F. Hoffmeister for seven days in December 1952.  Hoffmeister (1959) vaguely indicates fieldwork over the past several years, in both summer and winter, was conducted in southern Arizona.  Cook (1986) conducted a small mammal trapping study on the Animas Mountains; traps were placed within the major habitats of the mountains and trapping was conducted 26 February – 01 March 1981, 18 - 21 March 1981, 18 May – 05 August 1981, 07 – 13 October 1981, 19 December 1981 – 12 January 1982 and 12 – 17 March 1982.  This effort represented 11,000 trap nights.  Jones et al.  (2003) conducted a study in grazed and ungrazed grassland plots on and adjacent to the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch in Sonoita Valley, Santa Cruz County, Arizona with a total sampling effort of 5760 trap nights.

Southeast:
Fulvous harvest mouse occur primarily in grassy fields containing shrubs (Spencer and Cameron 1982). Additional habitat for this species includes fencrows, thickets, and pine-grass ecotones (Chaote et al. 1994, Wilson and Ruff 1999, Spencer and Cameron 1982).
Ecosystem Classifiers: Disturbed grasslands, Evergreen.

Great Plains:
In Texas, this species occurs admist tangles of grasses, weeds, and shrubs along creek bottoms. In Big Bend Ranch State Park they can be found within riparian woodlands, and mesquite desert scrub often traveling via small trails used be other associated small mammal species such as cotton and rice rats and white-footed mice. They live in underground burrows as well as arboreal refugia constructed out of existing material such as abandoned bird nests (Schmidly 2004).
